Title: The Rise and Fall of ESPN’s Leverage

Content: The Hollywood strike is setting talent against studios, but the problem is that both are jointly threatened by the reality of the Internet and zero distribution costs.

Title: Threads and the Social/Communications Map
Content: Understanding Threads and its threat to Twitter means understanding the current landscape of social media.

Title: Amazon, Friction, and the FTC
Content: The FTC’s Amazon complaint raises some fair points in isolation, but misses the bigger picture, both in terms of Amazon specifically and the Internet generally.

Title: Apple Vision
Content: Apple Vision is incredibly compelling, first as a product, and second as far as potential use cases. What it says about society, though, is a bit more pessimistic.

Title: What the NBA Can Learn From Formula 1
Content: Formula 1 has done an impressive job earning fans; the NBA should study it, because the pay TV bundle is slowly disintegrating

Content: More on Bing, particularly the Sydney personality undergirding it: interacting with Sydney has made me completely rethink what conversational AI is important for.

Content: Tech is increasingly divorced from the real economy thanks to the COVID hangover and Apple’s App Tracking Transparency

Title: Stratechery Plus Adds Greatest Of All Talk
Content: Announcing the newest addition to the Stratechery Plus bundle: Greatest of All Talk, a podcast about basektball, life, and national parks.

Title: The 2022 Stratechery Year in Review
Content: The most popular and most important posts on Stratechery in 2022.

Title: Consoles and Competition
Content: Reviewing the history of video games explains why Sony is dominant today, and why Microsoft is actually introducing competition, not limiting it.

Title: AI Homework
Content: The first obvious casualty of large language models is homework: the real training for everyone, though, and the best way to leverage AI, will be in verifying and editing information.

Title: Stratechery Plus Adds Sharp China with Sinocism’s Bill Bishop
Content: Stratechery Plus is expanding to include Sharp China with Sinocism’s Bill Bishop

Content: Explaining exactly why Apple’s approach to ATT is anti-competitive

Content: The reaction to the Ukraine invasion has been a demonstration of tech capabilities; those capabilities may be the key to compelling China to pressure Russia.

Content: Shopify should build an advertising business to complement Shop Pay and the Shopify Fulfillment Network

Content: The most popular and most important posts on Stratechery in 2021.

Content: Defining the Metaverse, and explaining why Microsoft is well-placed for the virtual reality opportunity

Content: Roblox is something new and interesting that abstracts away the platforms underneath it.

Content: The EU is back to regulating tech companies, and getting the Internet wrong in the process. That, though, helps illuminate an approach that could work.

Title: The iPhone Franchise
Content: The iPhone is a franchise, a product that will make money in well-defined ways; Apple understands that and is exploiting it more than ever before with the iPhones XS and XR.

Title: Uber’s Bundles
Content: Uber had a good strategy, but its crisis meant Lyft had new life and the strategy was no longer workable. Now the company is pursuing something new, even though it is more complicated.

Title: Facebook’s Story Problem — and Opportunity
Content: Snapchat is losing users, and it seems clear the biggest reason is Instagram Stories: that is a win for Facebook, but the pain in advertising may be substantial.

Title: Facebook Lenses
Content: Facebook was down dramatically after its last earnings; to decide if it is justified it is worth looking at the company through many different lenses, both financial and strategic.

Title: The European Commission Versus Android
Content: Examining the history of Android explains why the European Commission may be right to fine Google for its actions around Android, even as the reasoning feels off.

Title: Intel and the Danger of Integration
Content: Intel is in an increasingly bad position in part because it has been captive to its integrated model. Or, you could simply say they were disrupted.

Title: AT&T, Time Warner, and the Need for Neutrality
Content: It is no surprise that a judge allowed the AT&T-Time Warner acquisition to proceed given the government’s poor case; the question is if a better case could have been made. What is ultimately needed, though, are new laws.

Title: The Scooter Economy
Content: Scooters are everywhere, and the use case is amazing. What is not so clear, though, is how scooter companies can build strong businesses, which means consumers are the real winners.

Title: The Cost of Developers
Content: Microsoft paid a lot for GitHub, because it had to pay directly for access to developers. It doesn’t have the leverage of users the way that Apple does on the App Store.

Title: The Bill Gates Line
Content: Understanding the differences between aggregators and platforms matters for companies interacting with them and also regulators considering antitrust.

Title: The Moat Map
Content: The Moat Map describes the correlation between the degree of supplier differentiation and the externalization (or internalization) of a company’s network effect.

Title: Tech’s Two Philosophies
Content: Google and Facebook represent one philosophy, and Microsoft and Apple represent another; tech needs both, but ultimately platforms are more important than aggregators.

Title: Divine Discontent: Disruption’s Antidote
Content: Apple has long defeated disruption by focusing on the user experience; Jeff Bezos and Amazon, though, show that user expectations for their experience are ever-changing.

Title: Open, Closed, and Privacy
Content: Just as encryption is only viable on closed systems, so it is that increased privacy regulations will only entrench walled gardens. That should affect thinking on regulation.

Title: Zillow, Aggregation, and Integration
Content: Zillow fits the description of an aggregator, but it hasn’t transformed its industry due to a lack of integration. Now it is trying to do exactly that.

Title: The Facebook Current
Content: The Senate hearing about Facebook was a bigger deal than it might have seemed, both because it happened and because of what was said.

Title: The End of Windows
Content: The Windows division no longer exists at Microsoft, marking the end to a four-year process of changing Microsoft’s culture.

Title: Stratechery 4.0
Content: The newest version of Stratechery.com: now explore the site via concept, company, or topic, or use dramatically improved search functionality. Plus, a new logo!

Title: The Facebook Brand
Content: The Facebook brand is, due to Facebook’s strategic choices, about not respecting privacy. That is why the Cambridge Analytica story is such a problem for the company.

Title: Qualcomm, National Security, and Patents
Content: The Trump administration blocked Broadcom’s acquisition of Qualcomm, and I think it was the right move. Understanding why means understanding Qualcomm and Broadcom’s plan for the company — and the problem with patents.

Title: Lessons From Spotify
Content: Spotify has a marginal cost problem, but while the cause is unique to Spotify, the challenges are more applicable than it seems.

Title: The Dropbox Comp
Content: Dropbox has filed its S-1, but comparisons with Box, Atlassian, and Slack demonstrate how difficult it is to tell just how good its business is.

Title: The Aggregator Paradox
Content: Google is winning with AMP and blocking ads in Chrome: both seem bad, but aren’t they actually good for consumers? That is the paradox of aggregation.

Title: Apple’s Middle Age
Content: For Apple, hitting middle age means a strategy primarily focused on monetizing its existing customers. It makes sense, but one wonders what happens next.

Title: Amazon Health
Content: Amazon Health doesn’t seem like much now, but there are hints it could be the ultimate application of Aggregation Theory.

Title: Amazon Go and the Future
Content: Amazon Go exemplifies how Amazon is building its monopoly in three ways: horizontally, vertically, and financially. Plus, why automation is worth being optimistic about.

Title: Facebook’s Motivations
Content: The impact of Facebook’s News Feed changes on the media is far less interesting than what the changes — and their stated purpose — say about Facebook itself.

Title: Meltdown, Spectre, and the State of Technology
Content: Meltdown and especially Spectre are vexing vulnerabilities, precisely because processors are working as designed. All we can do is muddle through.

Title: The 2017 Stratechery Year in Review
Content: The most popular and most important posts on Stratechery in 2017.

Title: Disney and Fox
Content: Disney’s rumored acquisition of 21st Century Fox is all about competing with Netflix; whether or not that is a good thing depends on your frame of reference.

Title: The Pollyannish Assumption
Content: Moderating user-generated content is hard: it is easier, though, with a realistic understanding that the Internet reflects humanity — it is capable of both good and evil.

Title: Stitch Fix and the Senate
Content: Stitch Fix is a perfectly fine company that is a big startup success, in part because it paid attention to costs. It is very problematic that the Senate is threatening that, and potentially entrenching incumbents.

Title: Apple at Its Best
Content: Apple’s original competitive advantage — the integration of hardware and software — is more durable than disruption theory would suggest.

Title: Tech Goes to Washington
Content: Facebook, Google, and Twitter testified before a Senate committee: it provided evidence of how tech prefers power over decentralization, even if it means regulation

Title: Why Facebook Shouldn’t Be Allowed to Buy tbh
Content: Facebook is acquiring tbh, another burgeoning social network; regulators erred in allowing the Instagram and WhatsApp acquisitions, but there is no better place to start enforcing the law than now.

Title: Goodbye Gatekeepers
Content: Harvey Weinstein was a gate-keeper — a position that existed in multiple industries, including the media. That entire structure, though, is untenable on the Internet, and that’s a good thing.

Title: Google’s Search for the Sweet Spot
Content: Google’s hardware event shows the company’s commitment both to devices and to artificial intelligence; just doing what you are good at, though, is not always enough.

Title: Trustworthy Networking
Content: The problems Facebook are facing today are the result of running into the future without considering unintended consequences, much like Microsoft and the Internet. There are clear solutions for the ad problem, but the filter bubble issue is much more fraught.

Title: Defining Aggregators
Content: Building on Aggregation Theory, this provides a precise definition of the characteristics of aggregators, and a classification system based on suppliers. Plus, how to think about aggregator regulation.

Title: Books and Blogs
Content: Blogs are no longer a writing platform for new entrants; they are better than books for the ongoing development of ideas.

Title: The Super-Aggregators and the Russians
Content: Facebook is in trouble — again — for Russian ads about the election; figuring out how to deal with them requires first understanding that Facebook, like Google, is a Super-Aggregator. It faces zero transaction costs in all parts of its business.

Title: The Lessons and Questions of the iPhone X and the iPhone 8
Content: The iPhone X is a quintessential Apple product, because it is the best; is there a market for iPhone 8?

Title: Everything is Changing; So Should Antitrust
Content: WPP is dealing with not only a changing advertising industry but a changing world, thanks to the Internet. Antitrust needs to change as well.

Title: Uber’s New CEO
Content: Uber has a new CEO, and the reason he is a great choice explain why the Uber job is still an attractive one.

Title: Disney’s Choice
Content: Cable TV created a world where differentiated content could profit from everyone; that is why it will be hard for Disney to make the choices streaming will force on them.

Title: The Uber Dilemma
Content: Benchmark’s lawsuit against Uber is extraordinary; that is because Uber, despite everything, remains an extraordinary company. Game theory explains the implications.

Title: Apple and the Oak Tree
Content: Apple’s business, thanks to Services, is growing ever stronger, even as Apple loses the model — and the product — that made the company what it is today.

Title: Microsoft’s Monopoly Hangover
Content: There are striking similarities between Microsoft today and IBM in the Lou Gerstner era, but today’s IBM should be a warning to Redmond.

Title: Publishers and the Pursuit of the Past
Content: The newspaper industry is seeking an antitrust provision to negotiate for a return to a world that is gone and never coming back; worse, it is an approach that could ruin publishing’s true future.

Title: Ends, Means, and Antitrust
Content: Google is a monopoly, and almost certainly a bad actor: shopping, though, is a terrible example that shows how regulators can go wrong.

Title: Amazon’s New Customer
Content: The key to understanding Amazon’s purchase of Whole Foods is to understand that Amazon didn’t buy a retailer: the company bought a customer.

Title: Podcasts, Analytics, and Centralization
Content: The answer to podcast monetization is not analytics: it it true centralization, and it seems unlikely that Apple has it in them.

Title: Apple’s Strengths and Weaknesses
Content: Both Apple’s strengths and weaknesses were on full display at its annual WWDC keynote; the HomePod is a perfect example.

Title: Faceless Publishers
Content: The missing piece when it comes to the future of media are faceless publishers. Vox Media’s deal with The Ringer shows the way.

Title: Tulips, Myths, and Cryptocurrencies
Content: Did you hear the one about the tulip bubble? It’s almost certainly a myth. It is myths, though, that explain why cryptocurrencies are here to stay.

Title: Boring Google
Content: Google’s I/O was exactly what you would expect from Google, and that’s a great sign for the company.

Title: WannaCry About Business Models
Content: WannaCry is yet another systematic breakdown in security: the blame, though, is less with Microsoft and end users — nor the government — but rather a mismatched business model.

Title: The Local News Business Model
Content: Subscriptions are the future of local news: the key, though, is getting rid of newspapers.

Title: Apple’s China Problem
Content: Apple had mixed earnings: most of the world was great, but China was bad again. The reason is that in China WeChat matters more than iOS.

Title: Not OK, Google
Content: Google is making an algorithmic change to demote fake news, but its lack of transparency around its actions is concerning in its own right.

Title: Facebook and the Cost of Monopoly
Content: Facebook gave one of the worst keynotes in a long time: there was no vision, just the adoption of Snap’s. It’s the inevitable outcome of a monopoly.

Title: The Walt Mossberg Brand
Content: Walt Mossberg is retiring; his influence on tech is well-known, but his influence on the media is just as profound.

Title: The Arrival of Artificial Intelligence
Content: What is artificial intelligence? Is it really any different than technology? In my estimation machine learning is truly something new, and the effects on society will be significant.

Title: Ad Agencies and Accountability
Content: Google is in hot water again, this time for ads placed against objectionable content. However, ad agencies and brands are just as responsible, and can no longer live in the past.

Title: Intel, Mobileye, and Smiling Curves
Content: Intel is buying Mobileye; it’s an acquisition that makes sense once you realize how much value there is in components.

Title: The Uber Conflation
Content: It’s easy to conflate criticism of Uber’s regulatory approach with accusations about the company’s culture. That is CEO Travis Kalanick’s responsibility; it’s also a failure of all of tech.

Title: Twitter, Live, and Luck
Content: Last night’s Academy Awards show was another event that showed how special Twitter is; the fact that you had to be there shows just how badly the company has failed to evolve.

Title: Manifestos and Monopolies
Content: Facebook has long had too much power, but Mark Zuckerberg’s expressed willingness to use said power for political ends means it’s time to consider countermeasures.

Title: Snap’s Apple Strategy
Content: Snap plans to win on innovation; we’ve known for 30 years, though, that that is not always enough.

Title: Inspired Media
Content: The key for products and politicians used to be maximizing paid and earned media. What matters on the Internet, though, is inspired media.

Title: The Great Unbundling
Content: It’s trivial to say that the Internet changed media; what is more interesting is unpacking how different types of media were affected, and why — and what might happen to TV.

Title: The Ten Year Anniversary of the Apple TV
Content: Today is being marked as the 10-year anniversary of the iPhone; it is a footnote of history that it is also the 10-year anniversary of the Apple TV. It’s a reminder that we don’t know what innovations matter until they occur.

Title: Alexa: Amazon’s Operating System
Content: Money is made at chokepoints, and the most valuable chokepoints are operating systems; Amazon is building exactly that with Alexa.

Title: The 2016 Stratechery Year in Review
Content: The top posts on Stratechery in 2016

Title: The State of Technology at the End of 2016
Content: The annual Stratechery review of the state of technology, and call to build products that unlock human potential

Title: Opendoor: A Startup Worth Emulating
Content: OpenDoor has a unique yet high-risk approach to residential real estate; that’s a great thing, both for its prospects and for society.

Title: How Google Is Challenging AWS
Content: AWS seems to have a dominant position in enterprise computing, but Google is trying to change the rules to favor their inherent strengths.

Title: Fake News
Content: Facebook is under fire for fake news and filter bubbles; they are a problem, but most of the proposed solutions are far worse.

Title: Why Twitter Must Be Saved
Content: First, a reposting of an old Stratechery article, Rebuilding the World Technology Destroyed. Then, why Twitter is an essential antidote to Facebook and must be preserved.

Title: Apple Should Buy Netflix
Content: The fact Apple’s ‘TV’ app doesn’t have Netflix shows who has the leverage; Apple should just buy in.

Title: Surface Studio, Nintendo Switch, and Niche Strategies
Content: Microsoft’s Surface Studio and Nintendo’s Switch are exciting products because unlike previous failures, they start with the assumption that smartphones matter most

Title: The IT Era and the Internet Revolution
Content: The history of technology is of two distinct eras: information technology enhanced existing business. The Internet revolution is destroying them.

Title: Chat and the Consumerization of IT
Content: What does the consumerization of IT even mean? Workplace by Facebook, Skype Teams from Microsoft, and Slack offer three definitions.

Title: Google and the Limits of Strategy
Content: Google went wrong in the past by abandoning their horizontal business model; are they repeating their mistake, or does the future give them no choice?

Title: Snapchat Spectacles and the Future of Wearables
Content: Creating the future is not just about technology but about creating markets. Right now Snapchat is doing that as well as anyone, which bodes well for Spectacles (but don’t count out Apple).

Title: Oracle’s Cloudy Future
Content: Larry Ellison has declared that Oracle is a cloud company, but their customer offering seems more suited to the world that was.

Title: Facebook Versus the Media
Content: Facebook is in trouble with the media again, guilty of stupidity by apathy. Still, the media itself hasn’t exactly caught up with the reality of the Internet.

Title: Beyond the iPhone
Content: Apple’s event may have been lacking on the surface, but it laid the groundwork for innovations that will be revealed in time. And yes, it was courageous.

Title: Google, Uber, and the Evolution of Transportation-as-a-Service
Content: The competition between Uber and Google has broken out into the open: who has the advantage in the evolution of transportation-as-a-service, and who will likely win?

Title: The Sports Linchpin
Content: Ratings are down for the Olympics, which could be bad news not only for TV but industries everywhere.

Title: Walmart and the Multichannel Trap
Content: Walmart wasted years trying to retrofit their model to ecommerce. Buying Jet.com will give them a better chance, but it’s almost certainly too late to compete with Amazon.

Title: The Audacity of Copying Well
Content: Instagram copied Snapchat, and that’s a good thing: differentiation is about far more than features, and this is Facebook’s best shot at holding off Snapchat.

Title: Dollar Shave Club and the Disruption of Everything
Content: Dollar Shave Club is a textbook example of how the new Internet economy will destroy value in incumbent industries.

Title: A Technical Glitch
Content: Facebook Live is likely a lot more meaningful than Facebook expected: it’s a plus for society, but Facebook should expect more scrutiny. Given that, they have work to do when it comes to transparency.

Title: The Brexit Possibility
Content: Brexit’s downsides are clear; might tech help realize upsides in building something new based on a new world order?

Title: TV Advertising’s Surprising Strength — And Inevitable Fall
Content: TV advertising is having a good week at the upfronts, and it may be more resilient than expected. That, though, means the crash will be even more abrupt.

Title: Microsoft and Apple Double Down
Content: Both Microsoft and Apple made news yesterday, and while one was unexpected and the other predictable, both are effectively doubling down on their strategies. And both may not matter.

Title: The Future of Podcasting
Content: Podcasting is stuck between the open model of the past and the push for monetization in the future. Might there be a third way that actually benefits publishers?

Title: The Curse of Culture
Content: It is very fair to say that Apple is threatened by the potential rise of AI. Google, though, is also threatened by its inability to own customers’ attention. The solution for both companies may entail changing their culture, a very tall order indeed.

Title: Google’s Go-to-Market Gap
Content: Google is unique in that their business was built on being the best. The company, though, benefited from the open web. That is not the case in mobile.

Title: The Real Problem With Facebook and the News
Content: Facebook is receiving a lot of criticism for allegedly interfering with conservative topics when it comes to “Trending News”. In fact, though, the polarization reinforced by an engagement-driven feed is a much bigger concern.

Title: Everything as a Service
Content: We have likely reached Peak iPhone, and if not, it’s only a matter of time; physical goods can only scale so far. The future, thanks to the Internet, is everything-as-a-service

Title: Antitrust and Aggregation
Content: The European Commission’s antitrust case against Google is likely to be the first of many against aggregators, because the end game of Aggregation Theory is monopoly.

Title: Apple’s Organizational Crossroads
Content: A core part of what makes Apple Apple is its organization structure; Tim Cook has said it will never change. However, if Apple is serious about being a services company, change it must.

Title: Facebook, Phones, and Phonebooks
Content: There are two types of social networks, and Facebook wants to be both. The problem is that the company already chose public sharing over private communication.

Title: It’s a Tesla
Content: Tesla is not a disruptor, but then again, neither is Apple, the closest comp: both succeed by building a brand around being the best.

Title: Snapchat’s Ladder
Content: Snapchat is on the verge of conquering the toughest messaging market in the world: the United States. The way they did it is by laddering-up.

Title: Andy Grove and the iPhone SE
Content: Andy Grove passed away the same day that Apple announced the iPhone SE. One of Grove’s best decisions reminds me of this launch.

Title: The Amazon Tax
Content: Amazon is building a lot of businesses that look like AWS: taxes on major industries that work to everyone’s benefit. The reason, though, is that AWS is a lot like Amazon itself.

Title: Bitcoin and Diversity
Content: First, an exploration of the block size debate that is roiling the Bitcoin world, and then how lessons from that debate apply to diversity in tech.

Title: The Voters Decide
Content: An apolitical analysis of what is happening in U.S. politics through the lens of Aggregation Theory

Title: Apple, the FBI, and Security
Content: Apple versus FBI is being framed as a debate between privacy and security. In fact, though, there is a powerful argument to be made that Apple’s position is the more secure one for the United States.

Title: Zenefits and Regulation
Content: Zenefits fired its CEO after violating a number of regulations, and many people are drawing a connection to Uber. In fact, I think the situations are quite different; understanding why gives a framework for thinking about regulation.

Title: The Reality of Missing Out
Content: Tech is entering a period of inequality where the big winners lift the sector as a whole even as smaller companies suffer. The best example is Facebook, Google, and digital advertising.

Title: How Facebook Squashed Twitter
Content: Twitter uncovered the most powerful format in mobile back in 2006: the feed. But, in 2009, Facebook went algorithmic while Twitter remained to hard to use. Now, it’s almost certainly too late.

Title: The FANG Playbook
Content: The FANG companies — Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, and Google — are far more similar than you might think. Their rise in value is no accident, and it is connected to Aggregation Theory.

Title: Cars and the Future
Content: A massive revolution in cars seems right around the corner. However, I think it will take longer then most technologists think, but when it comes it will come quickly.

Title: A Politics For Technology
Content: Technology is changing the world, which means politics should change as well. There is a way forward that entails less regulation and a much bigger safety net.

Title: The 2015 Stratechery Year in Review
Content: The top five most read posts, big ideas, company-specific posts, posts about media, and Daily Updates of 2015.

Title: Slack and the State of Technology at the End of 2015
Content: Slack has announced the Slack Platform. It’s an obvious move, but it’s the obviousness that indicates what a huge opportunity it is

Title: Beyond Disruption
Content: Clayton Christensen claims that Uber is not disruptive, and he’s exactly right. In fact, disruption theory often doesn’t make sense when it comes to understanding how companies succeed in the age of the Internet.

Title: Selling Feelings
Content: Distribution being free may have ruined old business models, but it allows businesses to get much closer to their customers and make money by meeting needs.

Title: TensorFlow and Monetizing Intellectual Property
Content: Google has said repeatedly that machine learning is key to their future. Why, then, did they open source the secret sauce? Is it a mistake, or are there lessons to be learned for IP creators everywhere.

Title: Grantland and the (Surprising) Future of Publishing
Content: ESPN’s decision to close Grantland seems to be more evidence that there is no future outside of massive scale or one-man operations. Bill Simmons’ recent successes, though, suggest that the answer could be the exact opposite.

Title: In Defense of The New York Times
Content: Amazon and The New York Times had a fascinating exchange this week, on Medium of all places. What that exchange represents — the search for truth, now open to anyone — is far more important than the particular article in question.

Title: Venture Capital and the Internet’s Impact
Content: Venture Capital has been transformed by a surprising source: Amazon. Ultimately, no industry is safe from the impact of the Internet.

Title: Twitter’s Moment
Content: Twitter has had a rough stretch, and most are pessimistic about its chances. I was previously, but I think the upside is looking much brighter than it did before this week.

Title: The Facebook Epoch
Content: First came the PC, and on top of the PC the Internet. Then, mobile, but what will rule mobile?

Title: Disconfirming Ebooks
Content: Aggregation Theory would seem to argue that ebooks are destined to dominate the publishing industry. However, that is decidedly not happening; understanding why is a powerful tool to make the theory better.

Title: Popping the Publishing Bubble
Content: For years publishers haven’t had to worry about business models: they just captured attention and watched the money come in. Those days, though, are over: the publications that survive will start with business models and build journalism around it.

Title: From Products to Platforms
Content: Apple was at its best in its most recent keynote: unveiling the sorts of products the company is uniquely capable of creating. The question, though, is whether the company has the vision and capability of making those products into platforms.

Title: Uber 2.0: Human Self-Driving Cars
Content: Uber 1.0 is a huge success, but it’s still basically a taxi service. We know the future is self-driving cars, but is there an intermediary step? What if Uber could do self-driving cars today?

Title: Aggregation and the New Regulation
Content: Because of the Internet realities described by Aggregation Theory a smaller number of companies hold an increasing amount of power. However, an increasing focus on market forces reduces the latitude for bad behavior, and the incentives — and means — to hold those companies to account are greater than ever.

Title: Do You Trust Larry Page?
Content: With the establishment of Alphabet Larry Page is setting himself up to pursue his vision of how the world should be, and in the process challenging assumptions about how businesses should be run and the means through which progress is achieved.

Title: Why Disney and ESPN Will Be OK
Content: An increasing number of questions are being raised about the future of the pay-TV bundle, and of ESPN. The former may indeed be doomed, but that doesn’t mean the latter is in as much trouble as people think: after all, Disney is the master of differentiated content.

Title: The Case for Jack Dorsey, Twitter CEO
Content: For years Twitter has prioritized advertisers and revenue over users and product. The problem is that the latter begets the former, but not the other way around. Product must come first, which means Jack Dorsey should be Twitter’s CEO.

Title: Aggregation Theory
Content: The disruption caused by the Internet in industry after industry has a common theoretical basis described by Aggregation Theory.

Title: Why Web Pages Suck
Content: Everyone complains about web pages that suck, but the reality is that it is advertisers who call the shots. This should, at a minimum, put Facebook’s Instant Articles and Apple’s News app in a new light.

Title: Netflix and the Conservation of Attractive Profits
Content: Netflix has a lot more in common with Uber and Airbnb than you might think: it all comes back to the Law of Conservation of Attractive Profits, a core principle of disruption

Title: Airbnb and the Internet Revolution
Content: Airbnb gets less press than Uber, but in some respects its even more radical: understanding how it works leads one to question many of the premises of modern society from hotels to regulations. It’s an important marker in the Internet Revolution.

Title: Curation and Algorithms
Content: More and more companies are announcing new products based on human curation, even as the most important content players — Google and Facebook — rely on algorithms. When does curation make sense, and when are algorithms better? And ultimately, who is responsible for both?

Title: Unicorns
Content: There are a lot of unicorns, but not all unicorns are created equally: even if some die the value of them in aggregate is significant.

Title: Apple Music and Apple’s Focus
Content: Apple Music was a muddled mess, which raised the question of why it exists in the first place. Is it important anymore? More importantly, is Apple having trouble remembering how to focus?

Title: The Funnel Framework
Content: The Internet has removed scarcity, meaning business models based on controlling distribution are no longer viable. Instead, the key to success is controlling access to the best customers — and that means being the best.

Title: 21 Inc. and the Future of Bitcoin
Content: Bitcoin is commonly characterized as an alternative currency, but actually the core concept has little to do with money. The potential as a protocol is massive, but only if everyone everywhere is connected to the network. 21 Inc. is trying to make that happen.

Title: Apple Watch and Continuous Computing
Content: The Apple Watch’s success depends on three things: the physical design, the interaction model, and how it interacts with its environment. It’s on the right track

Title: Verizon-AOL, Facebook Instant Articles, and the Future of Digital Advertising
Content: Two seemingly unrelated stores — Verizon buying AOL. and Facebook offering publishers the option of Instant Articles — are actually very much connected: advertising online is undergoing a fundamental shift, and while there will be a few big winners, there will be a lot more losers.

Title: The AWS IPO
Content: AWS has long been a question mark when it comes to Amazon: it’s a good idea, and it makes money, but like it’s parent company, will it ever be profitable? The revelation that AWS is already very profitable indeed is a really big deal both for AWS but also for Amazon itself.

Title: Twitter Needs New Leadership
Content: Yesterday Twitter released very disappointing quarterly results, with misses on both user and revenue growth. From the Wall Street Journal: Twitter Inc. delivered its weakest quarterly revenue growth as a publicly traded company, casting a shadow on its fledgling advertising business, which until now has been a consistent bright spot. Investors, who sent the company’s […]

Title: Facebook and the Feed
Content: In a week where much of the Internet was all atwitter about Mobilegeddon, Google’s pre-announced algorithm change that will favor mobile-friendly sites in mobile search results, a potentially far more impactful announcement was much more of a surprise: Facebook is tweaking the News Feed algorithm. This is a big deal for publishers in particular: according […]

Title: Twitter and What Might Have Been
Content: Twitter’s blog is generally a cheery place, with one big exception from 2012: the innocuously named Changes Coming in Version 1.1 of the Twitter API, and in particular, the section called “Changes to the Developer Rules of the Road” that attempted to put the kibosh on 3rd-party Twitter clients:1 If you are building a Twitter […]

Title: It’s Not 1999
Content: The question of whether or not we are in a tech bubble has been raised regularly for years now; 2012, particularly Facebook’s acquisition of an app1 called Instagram for a ridiculous2 $1 billion, was a particular high point. The fact that Instagram is now valued at $35 billion suggests the 2012 doomsayers were just a […]

Title: Tidal and the Future of Music
Content: Predicting success and failure is about understanding who has leverage. In the case of music, the winners will be the labels, not the artist. But perhaps there is hope for tomorrow

Title: The Facebook Reckoning
Content: Publishers are wringing their hands about whether or not to utilize Facebook’s Instant Articles, but the truth is most have no choice

Title: The Changing — and Unchanging — Structure of TV
Content: The way we get TV may be changing, but the importance and defensibility of great content will persist

Title: How Apple Will Make the Wearable Market
Content: Last fall, Apple CEO Tim Cook described the Apple Watch as the “next chapter” in Apple’s history, placing it at the same level as the Mac, iPhone and iPod. I get the sense that a lot of people don’t believe him; they just don’t see the need for a wearable. There is ample precedent for […]

Title: Why BuzzFeed is the Most Important News Organization in the World
Content: The key to sustainable, ethical journalism is aligning the business and editorial sides of a publication. No company has done a better job of doing that on the Internet then BuzzFeed

Title: Old-Fashioned Snapchat
Content: How Snapchat is positioning itself to win an outsized share of television’s brand advertising

Title: Redmond and Reality
Content: Microsoft’s dominance in enterprise software was built on the difficulty of managing software installations; SaaS removes that linchpin entirely.

Title: Apple’s New Market
Content: If the importance of an integrated experience matter more with your phone than your PC, because you use it more, how much more important is an integrated experience that touches every detail of your life?

Title: Blogging’s Bright Future
Content: Blogs may not be the only means of expression on line, but they are a more viable as a business for writers focused on niches than ever before.

Title: Bad Assumptions
Content: John Gruber is, as only he can, relishing the claim chowder – his collected bits of analyst wisdom sure, again and again, that Apple is doomed. Apple, of course, is not doomed. In fact, the company is the very opposite of doomed, having just posted the best quarter of any company, ever.1 The analysts Gruber […]

Title: Dear Zoë Keating: Tell YouTube to Take a Hike
Content: Zoë Keating is an example of a new kind of content creator who can best maximize their revenue by going direct to consumers.

Title: The End of Trickle-Down Technology
